awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Meta-Analysis of the Effects of Refutation Materials for Promoting Conceptual Change in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
Individuals can develop misconceptions from many sources, ranging from incorrect information in online searches to experiences of everyday life.  An example is the persistence of thinking that winter happens because the earth is further away from the sun and summer happens because it is closer.  (The earth is about the same distance away in both seasons, but the earth's tilt affects the angle at which the sun's rays hit the surface of the northern versus southern hemispheres.)  Misconceptions can be very persistent, surviving college physics courses and other educational interventions.  One strategy for overcoming misconceptions is the use of refutation materials, which include texts, graphics, videos, and activities. Refutation materials explicitly activate incorrect prior knowledge, prompting the learner to recall their prior incorrect conception at the same time as they process the new correct conception. This co-activation of correct and incorrect models increases the probability that the learner will notice the discrepancies and strive to reconcile them, thus influencing learning. However, some researchers have recently called for caution when using refutation approaches to correct misconceptions because, sometimes when students are presented with certain refutations, they become more entrenched in their misconception. This reaction is called the "backfire effect" and is especially troubling since "just adding knowledge" rarely facilitates conceptual change. It is difficult to determine whether refutation materials will promote conceptual change or further strengthen misconceptions. This proposal aims to enhance STEM literacy by helping STEM educators understand when refutation might be best used to improve STEM knowledge.

The goals of this research synthesis are to study 1) the heterogeneity among the average effects of refutation materials on conceptual change and learning in STEM domains and 2) the factors (design, contextual, methodological, etc.) that foster or inhibit the effectiveness of refutation materials. To address this need, the project will use state of the art meta-analytic techniques to comprehensively search for studies about refutation, synthesize the findings, and identify factors that moderate the effects of refutation materials. The project is designed to advance the field and provide teachers, practitioners, and science communicators with a valuable resource by determining what type of refutation materials work, for whom, and under what conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Introduction. Research has shown that erroneous beliefs are highly resistant to change, posing considerable challenges to students' scientific literacy. Refutation texts have shown promise for facilitating conceptual change by prompting the learner to actively integrate incoming information with prior knowledge. Given its promise, there has been a recent surge of evidence focused on refutational text interventions. However, there has yet to be conducted a comprehensive synthesis using state-of-the-art synthesis methods to assess the cumulative evidence. This project employed state-of-the-art meta-analysis techniques to characterize the effectiveness of refutation texts compared to non-refutation texts and examined the conditions under which they most induce or inhibit conceptual change. The results provide valuable information to both educators and researchers on the features of refutational texts that are most effective, as well as the samples, settings, and outcomes for which benefits are most pronounced.

 

Purpose of the Meta-Analysis. The goal of this project was to provide valuable information, grounded in evidence, on the extent to which refutation text interventions are associated with science learning outcomes and the sample (e.g., initial knowledge accuracy, school level), setting (e.g., educational setting, subject), text (e.g., text cohesion, narrativity, controversiality of topic), comparison (one- or two-sided non-refutational text), outcome (e.g., post-test learning, change in learning, emotions, type of learning measure), and methods (e.g., random assignment, measure reliability) factors that influence effectiveness. 

 

Search and Inclusion Criteria. We conducted comprehensive database searches and direct contact search strategies to identify studies that focused on the effectiveness of refutation text interventions on learning and motivation outcomes. Approximately 7,741 reports in total were identified and screened. A total of 71 reports containing 76 studies, 294 effects and 25,201 unique participants from 111 independent samples were included in the meta-analysis. To be included in the meta-analysis, studies had to meet the following selection criteria: (a) contrasts the effects of a refutational text with a non-refutational control text condition focused on the same science content; (b) assesses post-intervention beliefs or other emotion or motivation outcomes; (c) reports information needed to calculate effect sizes; (d) conducted with typical functioning students (i.e., those without behavioral or emotional challenges); (e) reported in English language; (f) participants were randomly assigned to groups, or another approach was used to control for pre-existing group differences such as pretests or other matching procedures; and (g) interactive instruction was not included. 

 

Results: Findings indicated that refutation text interventions are effective. In line with the hypothesis that refutation texts enhance accurate beliefs, the overall mean weighted effect sizes for accurate beliefs were different from zero and in the small-to-medium range. The magnitude of effect was similar whether focused on post-refutation text exposure only learning outcomes, gIG = 0.37, p < .001 or the change in learning from pre- to post-exposure to the refutation texts, gIGRM = 0.36, p < .001. Likewise, in line with the hypothesis that refutation texts reduce inaccurate beliefs, the overall mean weighted effect sizes for inaccurate beliefs were also in the small-to-medium range. Again, average effects were similar across post-intervention only learning outcomes, gIG = -0.38, p < .001 and the change in learning from pre- to post-intervention exposure gIGRM = -0.31, p < .002. In contrast to hypotheses, the effect of refutation texts on positive emotions (gIG = 0.24, p = .35), negative emotions (gIG = -0.04, p = .71), and attitudes (gIG = 0.08, p = .36) were not significantly different from zero. Across 26 factors identified as potential moderators of the effect of refutation text on learning, none explained variation in effects. These moderator analyses suggest that refutation text effects were robust across circumstances, including across type of belief, initial understanding, publication status, randomization method, education setting, education levels, gender of the sample, country level of trust in science, continent, subject, controversial nature of the topic, type of control group, relative text length, relative and mean characteristics of the text, type of outcome, and the reliability and timing of the outcome measure. 

 

Theoretical and Practical Implications: Overall, our findings show a consistent and significant advantage of refutation text over expository texts in controlled experiments in confronting scientific misconceptions. The evidence provided in this synthesis suggests that refutation texts consistently outperform their expository counterpart with little variation in effects across different designs, groups of individuals, settings, topics, or measures. For practitioners who are attempting to communicate scientific findings to the general public, we suggest the adoption of refutational communication styles over traditional expository approaches. We do see refutations as playing an important role in debunking increasingly widespread and sometimes harmful misinformation in K-12, higher education, and science communications targeting the general public. Refutational approaches may prove especially useful in scenarios where science educators and communicators must engage in one-way communication (asynchronous learning, public service announcements, static websites, and commercials, for example, where interaction is not possible).
